Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the critical drop-off point between elementary and middle school, often identified as the first major roadblock to the success and interest of students in STEM. To help elementary students successfully transition to middle school science, the Principal Investigator will design, implement and test a model after-school program (Middle School Science Readiness program) aimed at supporting science teaching and learning at this critical juncture. The model uses year-long activities in real-world science, technology, engineering, and mathematics fields such as aerospace (NASA-Johnson Space Center), energy (petrochemical industry), and biotechnology (Texas Medical Center). Sixteen teachers and 320 students from eight high need elementary schools in Houston will participate in this after-school program.

Through a longstanding partnership with the Houston Independent School District (HISD), Baylor College of Medicine (BCM) will engage an interdisciplinary project team (e.g., university faculty members from STEM disciplines, educational psychologist, data managers, online education providers, principals, teacher leaders, and parents) to develop the model program. Within the STEM learning experiences, the project embeds language and social skills that support career awareness in STEM related fields.

The PI uses a quasi-experimental design and an external evaluator for methodology and assessment, respectively. The project will disseminate the model after-school program without charge, locally and nationally via BCM award-winning websites, BioEd Online (www.bioedonline.org), and K8 Science (www.k8science.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Middle School Science Readiness Program was designed to address the critical drop-off in science interest and achievement between elementary and middle school through after school activities for fifth grade students. Scientists and educators at Baylor College of Medicine developed and evaluated an after school program model to improve students’ science learning experiences, skills development (including language and social skills needed for middle school science) and career awareness related to STEM fields. The three units that were developed and evaluated are: Think Like an Engineer, Think Like an Astronaut and Think Like a Microbiologist.

Field tests of the three units of informal learning activities provided evidence that the units enhanced student learning of science content knowledge and helped develop students' skills related to science vocabulary use, working in collaborative groups, and testing and evaluating different solutions to a problem. Students in the after school programs had greater content knowledge gains and more improved attitudes toward science and science careers, than similar groups of students in the same schools, who did not participate in the after school programs.

In addition, project outcomes provide evidence that after school programs, such as the MIddle School Science Readiness Program, have potential to increase students’ awareness of and enthusiasm for science as a discipline and as a possible career option; as well as strengthen their science skills and preparedness for further science studies.

The project also found that teachers successfully are able to plan and implement afterschool programs focused on STEM topics, when they are provided with the tools (curriculum and materials) to do so. Teacher retention in the program was 94%.

The teaching materials created by the project are available free-of-charge on the science education website, BioEd Online (www.bioedonline.org).
